questions.text: A 65-year-old man with COPD was intubated for 5 days due to respiratory failure. He improved with mechanical ventilation and was extubated. On day 2 post-extubation, he developed fever, a productive cough with yellow-green sputum, and leukocytosis. A chest X-ray is taken and is shown below. What is the most likely cause of his pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), even in post-extubation cases once the patient is no longer ventilated.

  • Epidemiology
    • Streptococcus pneumoniae remains the leading cause of CAP across all age groups.
    • Common in elderly patients and those with underlying COPD.
  • Clinical presentation
    • Sudden onset fever, productive cough with purulent (often yellow-green or rust-colored) sputum.
    • Leukocytosis is a typical laboratory finding.
  • Radiology
    • Lobar consolidation pattern on chest X-ray is classically seen in pneumococcal pneumonia.
  • Timing in this case
    • The patient developed pneumonia after extubation, meaning he is no longer in the ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) category.
    • Thus, CAP organisms like Streptococcus pneumoniae are more likely than hospital-acquired Gram-negatives.

Explanation of other options

Aspiration pneumonia (Option B):

  • More common in patients with swallowing dysfunction, altered sensorium, or witnessed aspiration.
  • Produces anaerobic infection and foul-smelling sputum, usually involving dependent lung lobes.

Pseudomonas pneumonia (Option C):

  • Seen in ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or patients with structural lung disease/long-term hospitalization.
  • Since pneumonia developed after extubation, Pseudomonas is less likely here.

Staphylococcal pneumonia (Option D):

  • Often follows influenza or seen in debilitated/immunocompromised patients.
  • Classically causes multiple cavitating abscesses rather than simple lobar consolidation.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man presents with 3-4 months of malaise, 9.5 kg weight loss, and night sweats. He has a history of angina and arthritis. On exam, he is febrile, has clubbing, hepatosplenomegaly, and bibasal crepitations. Lab investigation shows Hb 9.1 g/dL, WBC 12,300/μL (52% neutrophils, 39% lymphocytes). Chest X-ray reveals 1-2 cm miliary nodules throughout both lungs. Mantoux test is negative, and blood cultures show no growth. His X-ray is shown below.

What are the probable causes of the illness and the X-ray finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Miliary tuberculosis presents with systemic symptoms, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and diffuse small nodules (1–2 mm) across both lungs on chest X-ray.

  • Definition
    • Miliary TB occurs due to hematogenous dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
    • Produces multiple millet seed-like nodules (<2 mm, but may appear larger radiologically) distributed throughout both lungs.
  • Clinical features
    • Prolonged constitutional symptoms: fever, weight loss, malaise, night sweats.
    • Organomegaly (hepatosplenomegaly) is common due to systemic spread.
    • Clubbing may occur in chronic disease.
  • Laboratory findings
    • Normocytic normochromic anemia (Hb 9.1 g/dL here).
    • Leukocytosis or lymphocyte-predominant response possible.
  • Mantoux negativity
    • In disseminated TB, Mantoux may be negative due to anergy (immunosuppression or overwhelming infection).
  • Radiological hallmark
    • Chest X-ray: bilateral, diffuse, uniformly sized miliary nodules.
    • These nodules are usually 1–2 mm in size but can appear larger on plain X-ray.

Explanation of incorrect options

Sarcoidosis (Option A):

  • Usually shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and interstitial infiltrates, not discrete miliary nodules.
  • Chronic course with non-caseating granulomas, not systemic toxicity like fever and weight loss.

Mycoplasma pneumoniae (Option B):

  • Causes atypical pneumonia with patchy interstitial infiltrates, not a miliary pattern.
  • Presents with dry cough, pharyngitis, and extrapulmonary features, not hepatosplenomegaly.

Staphylococcal pneumonia (Option C):

  • Produces rapid, necrotizing pneumonia with cavitation/abscesses, not diffuse micronodules.
  • Usually acute and severe, not chronic with months of symptoms.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman has had a history of dry cough for 2 months. She has lost 5 kg of weight over the past 2 months. Her chest X-ray shows left apical shadowing. Blood tests reveal a raised white cell count of 16250/µL. She has not managed to cough up any sputum. Which test should be performed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bronchoscopy is indicated to obtain tissue/sputum samples when sputum is not available, especially in suspected lung cancer or tuberculosis.

  • The patient has chronic cough, weight loss, leukocytosis, and an apical lung shadow, which strongly suggests an underlying malignancy or tuberculosis.
  • Since sputum could not be obtained for microbiological/ cytological diagnosis, bronchoscopy provides direct visualization and allows biopsy or washings.

Utility of investigations for lung pathologies:

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presented with a history of recurrent Haemoptysis. He has previously been treated for tuberculosis. The chest x-ray showed a rounded soft tissue mass within a cavity in the right upper lobe, accompanied by an air crescent.

What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A fungus ball (aspergilloma) develops within pre-existing lung cavities, classically after tuberculosis, and appears as a rounded mass with an air crescent sign.

  • Patients with prior TB often develop residual lung cavities, which serve as a nidus for colonization by Aspergillus fumigatus.
  • On chest X-ray, aspergilloma is seen as a rounded soft tissue mass inside a cavity, often moving with posture, surrounded by a crescent of air (“air crescent sign”).
  • Clinically, it presents with recurrent hemoptysis, which can range from mild to massive and life-threatening.
  • Other listed conditions do not produce a fungus ball or air crescent sign, making aspergilloma the most likely diagnosis here.

Explanation of incorrect options

Chlamydia pneumonia (Option A): Causes atypical pneumonia with diffuse infiltrates, not a cavity with a fungus ball.

Caplan's syndrome (Option B): Occurs in rheumatoid arthritis with pneumoconiosis, producing multiple rounded opacities, not cavity colonization.

Extrinsic allergic alveolitis (Option C): Hypersensitivity pneumonitis with diffuse ground-glass or nodular changes, not cavitary lesions.

questions.text: A 40-year-old HIV-positive man presents with progressive breathlessness. On examination, he desaturates on exertion. CD4 count is 120 cells/mm³. A chest X-ray is taken and is shown below. What should be commenced?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

HIV patients with CD4 <200 cells/mm³ are at high risk of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP), for which co-trimoxazole is the treatment of choice.

  • The patient is HIV-positive with CD4 count of 120, which is below the threshold of 200 where PJP commonly occurs.
  • PJP presents with progressive exertional dyspnea, dry cough, fever, and exertional desaturation.
  • Chest X-ray often shows bilateral, diffuse, interstitial infiltrates (sometimes normal early).
  • Co-trimoxazole (TMP-SMX) is both the drug of choice for treatment and also used for prophylaxis in HIV patients with CD4 <200.
  • Other antibiotics listed do not cover Pneumocystis jirovecii.

Explanation of incorrect options

Amoxicillin (Option A): Used for bacterial community-acquired pneumonia, not effective against PJP.

Amoxicillin and clarithromycin (Option B): Combination therapy for atypical/bacterial pneumonia; not indicated in PJP.

Doxycycline (Option D): Used for atypical pneumonias (e.g., Mycoplasma, Chlamydia); not useful in PJP.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male with a 5-year history of bronchial asthma presents with 20 days of worsening breathlessness, fever, cough, and mucoid sputum. He was previously well controlled on a budesonide metered dose inhaler. On examination, temperature 38.2°C, bilateral widespread wheeze. Investigation shows white blood cell count 13,000/µL, eosinophil count 4 × 109/L, serum immunoglobulin E level 800 kIU/mL. Chest X-ray shows infiltrates in the right mid and lower lung zones.

What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Allergic Bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) occurs in asthmatic patients with eosinophilia, elevated IgE, and pulmonary infiltrates due to hypersensitivity to Aspergillus.

  • This patient has long-standing asthma, now presenting with fever, cough, worsening wheeze, and sputum production.
  • Marked eosinophilia (4 × 109/L) and very high serum IgE (800 kIU/mL) strongly suggest an allergic hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Chest X-ray showing transient pulmonary infiltrates in the right mid and lower zones is typical of ABPA.
  • ABPA is caused by hypersensitivity to Aspergillus fumigatus colonizing the bronchi, leading to recurrent infiltrates, bronchiectasis, and poorly controlled asthma.

Explanation of incorrect options

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (Option A): Occurs in smokers; not associated with eosinophilia or raised IgE.

Pulmonary embolism (Option C): Presents with acute dyspnea, pleuritic pain, hemoptysis; no eosinophilia or high IgE.

Extrinsic allergic alveolitis (Option D): Hypersensitivity pneumonitis from inhaled organic dusts; presents with diffuse interstitial infiltrates and restrictive lung disease, not asthma with eosinophilia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with headache, cough, myalgia, and fever. On examination, she is pyrexial with bilateral scattered crackles on chest auscultation. She has been clinically diagnosed with Mycoplasma pneumonia. A rapid cold agglutinin test is positive. Which microbiological test is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is the most sensitive and specific microbiological test for confirming Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Mycoplasma Pneumonia:

  • Incubation period: 2-3 weeks.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Onset: Acute or subacute pneumonia.
    • Early symptom: Vague dyspnea.
    • Progression: Fever, nonproductive cough, worsening shortness of breath.
    • Severe cases: May lead to respiratory failure and death.
    • Extrapulmonary involvement is rare but can affect lymph nodes, spleen, and liver.
  • Physical Examination:
    • Decreased oxygen saturation at rest or exertion.
    • The chest exam may initially be normal, but it may later develop signs of diffuse rales and consolidation.
  • Diagnostic Tests:
    • Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR): (Option C)
      • Preferred test
      • Rapid, sensitive, and specific when available
    • Cold Agglutinin Test:
      • Can be supportive in urgent settings
      • Not specific
    • Gram Stain and Bacterial Cultures: (Option A, B, & D)
      • Not useful
      • Mycoplasma pneumoniae:
        • Lacks a cell wall
        • It is fastidious and difficult to culture
        • Requires special media and 7-21 days to grow
    • Serologic Tests:
      • Not perfectly sensitive or specific.
  • Chest X-ray Findings:
    • Most common findings include:
      • Reticulonodular pattern
      • Patchy consolidation
      • May be unilateral or bilateral
      • More commonly seen in the lower lobes.

Explanation of incorrect options

Sputum Gram stain (Option A): Mycoplasma has no cell wall → cannot be visualized on Gram stain.

Ziehl-Neelsen stain (Option B): Used for acid-fast bacilli like Mycobacterium tuberculosis, not Mycoplasma.

Blood culture (Option D): Mycoplasma is difficult to grow; not routinely cultured from blood.

Reference: 

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430780/

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with a history of breathlessness of 4-6 weeks' duration. He initially had flu-like symptoms and was treated by his doctor with a 5-day course of amoxicillin. However, he then started coughing up blood, leading to urgent referral. On examination, he was dyspnoeic at rest, with bilateral crackles on auscultation of the lungs. Investigation revealed anaemia and impaired renal function (creatinine 2.83 mg/dl). Pulmonary function tests were normal apart from an abnormally high diffusion factor. Urine dipstick testing showed the presence of red blood cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Goodpasture's syndrome is characterized by pulmonary hemorrhage and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis due to anti-GBM antibodies.

  • The patient has hemoptysis, dyspnea, bilateral lung crackles, anemia, and renal impairment, suggesting a pulmonary-renal syndrome.
  • The abnormally high diffusion capacity (DLCO) is a key clue, caused by increased uptake of CO due to intra-alveolar hemorrhage.
  • Presence of hematuria and raised creatinine indicates glomerulonephritis.
  • Goodpasture's syndrome is caused by autoantibodies against type IV collagen in glomerular and alveolar basement membranes.
  • Typical presentation: young male, hemoptysis, pulmonary infiltrates, anemia, and rapidly progressive renal failure.

Explanation of incorrect options

Farmer's lung (Option B): A hypersensitivity pneumonitis due to moldy hay exposure, presents with diffuse interstitial infiltrates and restrictive PFTs, not pulmonary hemorrhage + renal failure.

Invasive Aspergillosis (Option C): Seen in immunocompromised patients; causes fever, chest pain, nodules, cavitation-not pulmonary hemorrhage with glomerulonephritis.

Extrinsic allergic alveolitis (Option D): Another term for hypersensitivity pneumonitis; features restrictive defect, not pulmonary-renal syndrome.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with pneumonia is being examined. Which one of the following positive auscultatory signs is diagnostic of bronchial breathing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Whispering pectoriloquy is highly specific for bronchial breathing, indicating consolidation with patent bronchi.

  • In pneumonia, alveolar consolidation allows sound transmission much more clearly than normal aerated lung.
  • Whispering pectoriloquy is when whispered sounds are heard distinctly over the chest wall, which is diagnostic of consolidation and therefore bronchial breathing.
  • It is considered more reliable than aegophony or increased vocal resonance for identifying consolidation.
  • Bronchial breathing itself is caused by transmission of central bronchial sounds through consolidated lung tissue where alveoli lose their normal dampening function.

Explanation of incorrect options

Rhonchi (Option A): Musical sounds due to airway obstruction by secretions; seen in asthma/bronchitis, not diagnostic of bronchial breathing.

Increased vocal resonance (Option B): Suggests consolidation but is less specific compared to whispering pectoriloquy.

Aegophony (Option C): Nasal bleating quality of voice sounds, occurs in consolidation with a thin layer of pleural effusion, not specific for bronchial breathing.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old intravenous drug user is referred to the medical ward with complaints of chronic cough with sputum, weight loss, and night sweats. On examination, he appears unkempt and emaciated, with tracheal deviation to the left and crepitations over the left lung apex. Chest X-ray reveals fibrosis and cavitation in the left upper lobe. A Ziehl-Neelsen stain of sputum is shown below:

Which organism is most likely responsible for this patient's illness?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of acid-fast bacilli on Ziehl-Neelsen stain, along with upper lobe cavitation and systemic symptoms, strongly suggests Mycobacterium tuberculosis as the causative organism.

Diagnosis of Tuberculosis (TB):

  • Clinical Suspicion:
    • Suspect TB in patients with chronic cough, weight loss, fever, and risk factors (e.g. HIV, immunosuppression).
    • Classic chest X-ray: Upper-lobe infiltrates ± cavities.
    • Atypical findings in elderly/HIV (e.g. lower-lobe or interstitial patterns).
  • Key Diagnostic Tools:
    • Molecular Tests (First-line):
      • Xpert MTB/RIF:
        • Detects TB & rifampin resistance.
        • High sensitivity, especially in HIV and smear-negative cases.
      • Truenat MTB / MTB-Rif Dx (India):
        • Portable, good sensitivity/specificity, rifampin resistance detection.
      • TB-LAMP: For smear-negative pulmonary TB (does not detect resistance).
    • Smear Microscopy:
      • Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) stain or fluorescent stain.
      • Less sensitive; LED microscopy preferred by WHO.
    • Culture:
      • MGIT liquid culture: Gold standard, faster than solid media.
      • Solid media (LJ): Takes weeks.
      • Allows species identification and drug susceptibility testing (DST).
    • Drug Resistance Testing (DST):
      • Molecular LPAs: Detect resistance to rifampin, isoniazid, and second-line drugs.
      • Xpert & Truenat: Detect rifampin resistance.
      • WGS/tNGS: Emerging methods for comprehensive DST.
    • Imaging:
      • Chest X-ray: Sensitive but nonspecific.
      • CT/MRI: Useful in extrapulmonary TB (e.g., CNS, bone).
      • PET-CT: Detects subclinical/miliary TB.

Explanation of other options:

Nocardia asteroides (Option A): It is also acid-fast but usually affects immunocompromised patients and commonly causes pulmonary or brain abscesses, not classic apical cavitary tuberculosis-like disease in a drug user.

Actinomyces israelii (Option C): It is not acid-fast and typically causes cervicofacial or pelvic infections with sulfur granules, not cavitary lung lesions.

Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare (Option D): It affects severely immunocompromised individuals, especially those with AIDS, and causes disseminated disease, not localised apical cavitation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with epilepsy has been diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and is about to be started on quadruple therapy. Which drug may cause urine discolouration?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rifampicin causes orange-red discoloration of urine, sweat, tears, and other body fluids due to its chromophore structure.

  • Rifampicin is a first-line anti-tubercular drug that inhibits DNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
  • It has a characteristic side effect of orange-red discoloration of urine, sweat, saliva, and tears, which is harmless but often alarming to patients.
  • Patient counselling is important to avoid unnecessary concern.
  • Other adverse effects include hepatotoxicity, flu-like syndrome, thrombocytopenia, and multiple drug interactions due to induction of cytochrome P450 enzymes.
  • Hence, in TB patients (including this woman with epilepsy), rifampicin is the drug responsible for urine discoloration.

Explanation of incorrect options

Pyrazinamide (Option A): Causes hepatotoxicity, hyperuricemia, and arthralgia; does not discolor urine.

Erythromycin (Option B): A macrolide antibiotic, not part of standard TB therapy; main adverse effects are GI upset and QT prolongation.

Isoniazid (Option D): Causes peripheral neuropathy (prevented with pyridoxine) and hepatotoxicity; does not cause urine discoloration.

questions.text: A 55 year old farmer has had progressive breathlessness over the past 2 years. He presents with a severe episode of dyspnea and productive cough which occurred 6 hours after he started working. He mentions that these episodes are typical but today is more severe. On admission, his O2 saturations are 94% on air.CXR shows bilateral interstitial shadowing in upper zones.Which of the following is the most useful test?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Farmer's lung is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by Micropolyspora faeni, and detection of specific precipitating antibodies confirms the diagnosis.

  • The patient is a farmer with progressive dyspnea and recurrent episodes after exposure to moldy hay, which is strongly suggestive of Farmer's lung.
  • Farmer's lung is a type of extrinsic allergic alveolitis (hypersensitivity pneumonitis) caused by repeated inhalation of thermophilic actinomycetes, especially Micropolyspora faeni.
  • Clinical picture: Dyspnea, cough, fever, weight loss, and clubbing in chronic cases. Symptoms typically occur 4–8 hours after antigen exposure.
  • Chest X-ray: Bilateral upper zone interstitial shadowing, consistent with hypersensitivity pneumonitis.
  • Diagnostic test: Precipitins (IgG antibodies) to Micropolyspora faeni are highly useful and support the diagnosis.

Explanation of incorrect options

Precipitins to Aspergillus (Option A): Seen in Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA), usually in asthmatics or cystic fibrosis patients, not in farmer's lung.

Sputum for AFB (Option B): Used for tuberculosis diagnosis, not relevant here as symptoms are antigen-driven hypersensitivity.

Kveim test (Option C): Used for sarcoidosis diagnosis, not for hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with haemoptysis, cough, and dyspnoea. He has no prior medical issues but has a 10-year history of smoking (25 cigarettes/day). Chest X-ray reveals diffuse alveolar infiltrates. Blood tests show a microcytic, hypochromic anaemia. Urine dipstick is positive for both haematuria and proteinuria. Lung function tests show normal spirometry with a diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) of 125% predicted. A kidney biopsy immunofluorescence image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Goodpasture's syndrome is characterized by pulmonary haemorrhage and glomerulonephritis due to anti-GBM antibodies, showing linear IgG deposition on immunofluorescence.

  • The patient has respiratory symptoms (haemoptysis, dyspnea) + renal involvement (hematuria, proteinuria) → points to a pulmonary-renal syndrome.
  • CXR: Diffuse alveolar infiltrates → consistent with pulmonary haemorrhage.
  • Anaemia: Secondary to chronic pulmonary bleeding.
  • DLCO: Elevated (125% predicted) → due to increased carbon monoxide uptake in alveoli filled with blood (a hallmark of pulmonary hemorrhage syndromes).
  • Kidney biopsy IF: Linear IgG deposition along the basement membrane → diagnostic of Goodpasture's syndrome.
  • Pathogenesis: Autoantibodies directed against the α3-chain of type IV collagen in glomerular and alveolar basement membranes.
  • Classically affects young men who smoke, as smoking increases alveolar injury and risk of pulmonary hemorrhage.

Explanation of incorrect options

Pulmonary emboli (Option A): Causes sudden dyspnea, chest pain, and sometimes hemoptysis, but not glomerulonephritis or linear IgG on biopsy.

Chest trauma (Option B): Can cause pulmonary hemorrhage but does not explain renal findings or immunofluorescence results.

Pulmonary tuberculosis (Option D): Causes chronic cough, fever, night sweats, and cavitation; not associated with renal disease or anti-GBM antibodies.

Causes of increased DLCO:

  • Diffuse alveolar haemorrhage (Eg, Goodpasture syndrome)
  • Asthma
  • Polycythemia
  • Obesity

questions.text: A 60-year-old miner has been in the occupation for 20 years. He presents with a cough and breathlessness. Chest XR shows diffuse interstitial shadowing. A sputum sample is positive for acid-fast bacilli. Which of the following dusts is most likely to have predisposed the patient to tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Silica exposure predisposes to tuberculosis due to impaired macrophage function and inhibition of phagolysosome fusion.

  • Silicosis is an occupational lung disease caused by inhalation of crystalline silica dust, common in miners, sandblasters, and stone workers.
  • Radiology shows diffuse interstitial shadowing, often upper-lobe predominant.
  • Pathogenesis: Silica is toxic to alveolar macrophages, leading to apoptosis and impaired clearance of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Silica dust interferes with phagolysosome formation, increasing susceptibility to TB infection.
  • This strong association of silicosis with tuberculosis is termed silicotuberculosis.
  • Hence, the patient's occupation, radiology, and AFB-positive sputum confirm silica as the predisposing factor.

Explanation of incorrect options

Beryllium (Option A): Causes chronic berylliosis, a granulomatous lung disease resembling sarcoidosis, but not specifically linked to TB.

Cadmium (Option B): Toxic to kidneys and lungs, may cause obstructive lung disease, but not TB predisposition.

Coal (Option C): Causes coal workers' pneumoconiosis; associated with chronic bronchitis and PMF, but not strongly linked to TB like silica.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presented with a dry cough, thoracic constriction, and generalised weakness. During the preceding 5 months, she had experienced these dry cough episodes twice a week. A lung function test showed a restriction of the vital capacity (71% of the adjusted reference value), and the diffusion capacity was also reduced (66 to 68%). Bronchoalveolar lavage specimens were obtained, the lymphocytes were increased up to 41% (norm, <10%), and neutrophils were increased up to 6% (norm, <2%) with a normal total cell count. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Extrinsic allergic alveolitis (hypersensitivity pneumonitis) presents with restrictive lung function, reduced DLCO, and BAL lymphocytosis with increased neutrophils.

  • Clinical features: Subacute presentation of dry cough, chest tightness, and weakness, recurring with exposure, fits hypersensitivity pneumonitis rather than asthma or infection.
  • Pulmonary function test: Shows a restrictive pattern with reduced diffusion capacity (DLCO), typical of interstitial lung disease.
  • BAL findings:
    • Lymphocytosis >40% (normal <10%) → hallmark of hypersensitivity pneumonitis.
    • Mild neutrophilia is also supportive.
    • Total cell count is not elevated, ruling out infection.
  • Pathogenesis: Immune-mediated response to repeated inhalation of organic antigens (e.g., farmer’s lung due to Micropolyspora faeni).
  • These features together confirm extrinsic allergic alveolitis.

Explanation of incorrect options

Asthma (Option A): Shows an obstructive pattern on spirometry, with normal or increased DLCO; BAL shows eosinophilia, not lymphocytosis.

Pulmonary embolism (Option B): Presents acutely with dyspnea and pleuritic pain; does not cause BAL lymphocytosis or restrictive lung disease.

Tuberculosis (Option C): Causes granulomatous inflammation, productive cough, positive microbiology; BAL would show neutrophilia, not isolated lymphocytosis with restriction.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is admitted with malaise and fever. Four weeks previously, she had suffered a chest infection for which she was given a course of oral amoxicillin. She felt better initially, but is now getting worse, complaining of intermittent fevers. Her chest radiograph is shown below. An aspirate shows fluid with a protein of 42 g and pH of 7.0. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Empyema is suggested by fever, pleural fluid with high protein and low pH (<7.2), following pneumonia.

  • The patient had a recent pneumonia treated with antibiotics, followed by persistent fever and malaise, suggesting parapneumonic compli
  • Pleural fluid analysis:
    • Protein = 42 g/L → Exudate (since >30 g/L).
    • pH = 7.0 → Strongly suggests empyema, as pleural infection leads to anaerobic metabolism and accumulation of acidic byproducts.
  • Chest X-ray: Typically shows pleural-based opacity with fluid levels, often loculated.
  • Empyema is a collection of pus in the pleural space, usually complicating bacterial pneumonia, especially when treatment is inadequate.
  • Management involves antibiotics plus drainage (chest tube).

Explanation of incorrect options

Collapse of the left lung (Option A): Would show mediastinal shift and volume loss, but not exudative pleural fluid with low pH.

Serous pleural effusion (Option C): Transudates (e.g., CHF, nephrotic syndrome) have low protein (<30 g/L) and normal/high pH.

Tuberculosis (Option D): Can cause lymphocytic exudative effusion, but fluid pH is usually >7.3 and presentation is more chronic, not post-pneumonia with pus.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT employed in the laboratory diagnosis of respiratory viral infections?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Single radial haemolysis is used for detecting antiviral antibodies (serology), not for direct diagnosis of respiratory viral infections.

  • Respiratory viral infections (influenza, RSV, parainfluenza, adenovirus, etc.) are diagnosed by methods that detect virus directly or viral antigens.
  • Diagnostic methods include:
    • Immunofluorescence: Detects viral antigens directly in respiratory epithelial cells. (Option A ruled out)
    • Tissue culture: Used for virus isolation (though less commonly now, replaced by PCR). (Option B ruled out)
    • Hemagglutination: Detects viruses that agglutinate RBCs (e.g., influenza, parainfluenza). (Option C ruled out)
  • Single radial haemolysis (SRH): A serological method for detecting specific antibodies (e.g., to influenza), not used in acute diagnosis.
    • It is applied in immunology and vaccine evaluation, not in routine viral diagnosis.
  • Thus, SRH is NOT used for direct laboratory diagnosis of respiratory viral infections.

questions.text: A 45-year-old seaman presents with a cough and fever. A CXR demonstrates a cavitating lung lesion as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Histoplasmosis can cause chronic pulmonary infection with cavitating lesions resembling tuberculosis.

  • Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus endemic in many parts of the world, especially river valleys (Mississippi, Ohio, parts of India).
  • Infection occurs by inhalation of microconidia from soil enriched with bird/bat droppings.
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Acute infection may be asymptomatic or resemble influenza.
    • Chronic pulmonary histoplasmosis occurs in patients with underlying lung disease (smokers, seamen, miners) and mimics tuberculosis with upper lobe cavitation, cough, fever, weight loss.
  • Chest X-ray: Cavitary lesions, especially in chronic form, may resemble TB.
  • Seamen/miners are predisposed due to occupational exposures to endemic soil/dust.
  • Thus, the cavitating lesion in this clinical setting is most consistent with Histoplasmosis.

Causes of cavitary lesions in the lungs:

  • Infections (Pneumonia, lung abscess, septic emboli)
    • Bacteria (for example, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staph. aureus, Klebsiella pneumoniae, H. influenzae)
    • Typical and atypical mycobacteria
    • Fungi (for example, aspergillosis, pneumocystis j.)
    • Parasites
  • Non-infectious causes:
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
    • Rheumatic nodules
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Malignancy

Explanation of incorrect options

Syphilis (Option B): Tertiary syphilis can cause gummatous lesions but rarely produces cavitating pulmonary lesions; not a typical lung cause.

Sarcoidosis (Option C): Causes bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and diffuse reticulonodular pattern; cavitation is rare.

Amoebiasis (Option D): Causes liver abscess; lung involvement is via rupture of liver abscess → right-sided pleural effusion/empyema, not cavitating primary lung lesion.

questions.text: A 22-year-old lady recently returned from a holiday in Malta, was admitted with a 3-day history of fever, generalised lymphadenopathy and a macular rash over the trunk and legs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Infectious mononucleosis presents with fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, rash, and malaise due to EBV infection.

  • Infectious mononucleosis (IM) is caused by Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) and typically affects adolescents and young adults.
  • Classic triad: fever, pharyngitis, and generalized lymphadenopathy. Splenomegaly is also common.
  • A macular/maculopapular rash occurs in some patients spontaneously but is especially notorious after administration of amoxicillin or ampicillin in the setting of IM.
  • The patient’s short febrile course, diffuse lymphadenopathy, and rash following recent travel fits best with infectious mononucleosis.
  • Lab clues (not given but important for exams): lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes, positive heterophile antibody (Monospot test).

Explanation of incorrect options

Sarcoidosis (Option A): Presents with insidious onset, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, erythema nodosum; not acute febrile with rash.

Tuberculosis (Option B): Causes chronic illness with weight loss, night sweats, and localized lymphadenitis (scrofula); not acute generalized rash.

Familial Mediterranean Fever (Option C): Characterized by recurrent episodes of fever with serositis (peritonitis, pleuritis, arthritis), common in people of Mediterranean origin, but not associated with lymphadenopathy and rash.

questions.text: Which of the following would be the least likely finding in a patient with sarcoidosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sarcoidosis is associated with non-caseating granulomas but not with X bodies, which are seen in asbestosis.

  • Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease of unknown etiology. The hallmark is non-caseating granulomas in affected tissues (lungs, lymph nodes, skin, liver, etc.).
  • Hepatic granulomas are common in sarcoidosis, though often asymptomatic.
  • Restrictive pulmonary function tests (PFTs) occur due to interstitial lung involvement, showing reduced TLC and DLCO.
  • Skin lesions such as erythema nodosum and lupus pernio are classic features.
  • X bodies (ferruginous/asbestos bodies) are characteristic of asbestosis, not sarcoidosis. Hence, this is the least likely finding.

Explanation of incorrect options

Hepatic granulomas (Option A): Found in ~50–80% of sarcoidosis cases; usually incidental.

Restrictive pulmonary function tests (Option B): Typical in pulmonary sarcoidosis due to interstitial lung disease.

Skin lesions (Option C): Common manifestations include erythema nodosum and lupus pernio.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with ankylosing spondylitis presents with cough, weight loss and tiredness. His CXR shows longstanding upper lobe fibrosis. Three sputum tests stain positive for acid-fast bacilli but are consistently negative for Mycobacterium tuberculosis on culture. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare complex (MAC) causes pulmonary disease in patients with underlying lung pathology, showing AFB positivity but negative M. tuberculosis culture.

  • The patient has structural lung disease (upper-lobe fibrosis from ankylosing spondylitis) which predisposes to non-tuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) infection.
  • Sputum: AFB positive, but repeatedly negative for M. tuberculosis → classic for MAC.
  • Clinical features: Chronic cough, weight loss, fatigue; radiology often shows upper-lobe fibrocavitary disease in older men.
  • MAC organisms are opportunistic and affect patients with pre-existing lung damage (e.g., fibrosis, COPD, bronchiectasis).
  • Differentiation from TB is critical as treatment regimens differ.

Bacteria Displaying Acid Fastness:

  • Genus Mycobacterium: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycobacterium leprae, Mycobacterium smegmatis, Mycobacterium avium complex, Mycobacterium kansasii
  • Genus Nocardia: Nocardia brasiliensis, Nocardia cyriacigeorgica, Nocardia farcinica, Nocardia nova

Non-Bacterial Structures Showing Acid Fastness:

  • Bacterial endospores
  • Head of sperm
  • Cryptosporidium parvum
  • Isospora belli
  • Cyclospora cayetanensis
  • Taenia saginata eggs
  • Hydatid cysts
  • Sarcocystis
  • Nuclear inclusion bodies (in lead poisoning)

Explanation of incorrect options

Micropolyspora faeni (Option B): Causes hypersensitivity pneumonitis (Farmer’s lung), not cavitary AFB-positive disease.

Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (Option C): Causes asthma exacerbations, central bronchiectasis, eosinophilia; not AFB-positive or upper-lobe fibrosis.

Tuberculosis (Option D): Would grow on M. tuberculosis culture; repeated culture-negative AFB points toward NTM instead.

Reference: 

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537121/

questions.text: A 52-year-old man enquired about the advisability of vaccination before a holiday abroad. He had been treated for asthma with long-term steroids and regularly required doses of Prednisolone over 30mg daily to control acute exacerbations. Which one of the following vaccinations would be contraindicated in this man?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

BCG is a live attenuated vaccine and is contraindicated in immunosuppressed patients, including those on high-dose corticosteroids.

  • BCG vaccine: Live attenuated Mycobacterium bovis vaccine.
  • Contraindication: Immunocompromised patients, including those receiving prednisolone >20 mg/day for >2 weeks, due to risk of disseminated infection.
  • Other vaccines listed (toxoid or conjugate vaccines):
    • Diphtheria toxoid: Inactivated toxoid; safe in immunosuppressed individuals.
    • influenzae type B: Conjugate vaccine; safe in immunocompromised.
    • Meningococcus: Polysaccharide or conjugate vaccine; safe in immunosuppressed.
  • High-dose corticosteroids suppress cell-mediated immunity, increasing risk from live vaccines like BCG, measles, varicella, yellow fever.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Diphtheria toxoid (Option B): Inactivated vaccine; safe in immunocompromised.

H Influenzae B (Option C): Conjugate vaccine; safe in immunosuppressed.

Meningococcus (Option D): Polysaccharide/conjugate vaccine; safe for immunosuppressed.

questions.text: The following type of pulmonary TB is most likely to be associated with AFB sputum positivity:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cavitary pulmonary tuberculosis is more likely to be associated with Acid-Fast Bacilli (AFB) sputum positivity.

  • In cavitary TB, cavities or cavitations (hollow spaces or gaps) form within the lung tissue as a result of the disease process.
  • These cavities often contain a high concentration of mycobacteria, making it more likely for AFB to be present in the sputum of affected individuals.
  • Sputum from cavitary TB lesions is more infectious and has a higher likelihood of yielding positive AFB smear results compared to other forms of pulmonary TB.
  • Cavities represent necrosis of tissue, resulting in communication of the infected material with the airways.
  • The bacteria are thus discharged in the bronchial tree from where they can be coughed out with sputum.
  • The infected material can cause tubercular bronchopneumonia in the host by spreading to other parts of the lungs or gastro-intestinal tuberculosis using swallowed secretions.
  • The risk of spreading to other individuals is very high with cavitary tuberculosis.

Explanation of other options:

Primary complex (Option A): This is usually associated with the initial infection and may not always yield AFB-positive sputum.

Fibro nodular (Option B): While fibro nodular lesions can be seen in tuberculosis, they are not typically associated with the highest likelihood of AFB sputum positivity.

Pleural effusion (Option D): Tuberculous pleural effusion can occur, but it involves fluid in the pleural space rather than cavities within lung tissue. The presence of AFB in pleural effusion is less common compared to cavitary TB.

questions.text: Fibro-cavitary lung lesion on x-ray is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Post-primary TB occurs in immunocompetent hosts and causes caseating granulomas.

  • The caseous material gets drained out through the bronchi, resulting in small cavities surrounded by fibrosis.
  • Typically, there is involvement of:
    • Apical and posterior segments of the upper lobe
    • Superior segment of the lower lobe
  • Bilateral apical pulmonary cavities, better seen on the left. Patchy left upper zone consolidation. No pleural effusion.
  • Miliary TB is caused by hematogenous spread of TB bacilli and has a characteristic appearance on CT scan of the chest with randomly distributed lesions measuring 1-2 mm.
  • Primary complex is a small area of consolidation in subpleural parenchyma.
  • A lung abscess is a thick-walled cavity on X-ray.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding nucleic acid amplification (NAA) tests is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • FDA-Approved NAA Tests:
    • Amplicor Test (PCR-based)
      • For smear-positive specimens only
      • Results in 6-7 hours
    • Amplified MTD Test
      • For both smear-positive and smear-negative samples
      • Results in 3-4 hours
    • Xpert MTB/RIF Assay
      • Detects tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance
      • Results in ~2 hours
    • Automated and cartridge-based
  • Species Differentiation (Genotyping):
    • NAA tests can perform DNA fingerprinting
    • Helps distinguish different strains of tuberculosis complex
    • Useful for tracking transmission chains and public health planning
  • New Rapid Molecular Tests:
    • Truenat MTB and MTC Plus (Developed in India)
      • Sensitivity: 83% (MTB) and 89% (MTC Plus)
      • Rapid results, culture-comparable
  • Other Techniques:
    • Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification (LAMP):
      • DNA-based method, a faster alternative to microscopy

questions.text: For which of the following groups is the pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine not routinely recommended?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) is not routinely indicated in healthy adults aged 50–65; it is recommended for high-risk groups.

  • Pneumococcal vaccines:
    • PPSV23: Covers 23 serotypes; recommended for adults ≥65 years and adults 19–64 years with risk factors.
    • PCV13/15/20: Conjugate vaccines, recommended for high-risk adults.
  • Indications for adults 19–65 years: Those with: (Options B,C,D ruled out)
    • Immunocompromising conditions (HIV, splenectomy, chronic renal disease)
    • Chronic heart, lung (including asthma), or liver disease
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Cigarette smokers
  • Otherwise healthy adults aged 50–65: No routine vaccination unless additional risk factors are present.
  • Rationale: Vaccine efficacy and cost-effectiveness favor targeting high-risk populations rather than all healthy middle-aged adults.

questions.text: Urinary antigen is a useful test to detect which of the following organisms causes pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Urinary antigen testing detects cell wall polysaccharide of Streptococcus pneumoniae, allowing rapid diagnosis of pneumococcal pneumonia.

  • Principle: Detects pneumococcal C-polysaccharide antigen in urine; useful in patients who are already on antibiotics or when sputum samples are unobtainable.
  • Clinical utility:
    • Rapid, non-invasive test.
    • Sensitivity ~70–80%, specificity >90%.
    • Detects pneumococcal pneumonia including bacteremic and non-bacteremic cases.
  • Not useful for:
    • Haemophilus influenzae (Option A) → No urinary antigen test; requires culture or PCR.
    • Chlamydia trachomatis (Option B) → Causes atypical pneumonia; detected by PCR or serology.
    • Mycoplasma pneumoniae (Option D) → Atypical pneumonia; diagnosed by PCR or serology, not urinary antigen.

C&S: Culture & Sensitivity

PCR: Polymerase Chain Reaction

questions.text: Hospital-acquired pneumonia can be labelled if it develops after____hours after hospital admission.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) is defined as pneumonia developing ≥48 hours after hospital admission, not incubating at the time of admission.

  • Definition: HAP refers to pneumonia occurring 48 hours or more after admission, distinguishing it from community-acquired pneumonia.
  • Rationale:
    • The 48-hour cutoff ensures the infection was acquired in the hospital environment.
    • Early-onset HAP (<5 days) often involves antibiotic-sensitive organisms; late-onset HAP (>5 days) often involves multidrug-resistant pathogens.
  • Clinical relevance: Correct identification helps in selecting empiric antibiotics and implementing infection control measures.
